Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Expectation2: Provide clients with clear and accurate legal advice
Situation2: The client’s case grows more complex and requires detailed guidance
Story: The shrill wail of the evacuation alarm slices through the clamor of the construction site, and I drop my tools, heart pounding. As a laborer, I know the drill—protocol demands I leave everything and head straight to the muster point, no questions asked. My foreman’s eyes sweep the site, counting heads, and I feel the weight of the team’s safety on my shoulders. But my phone vibrates insistently in my pocket. It’s my client, desperate for guidance as their case takes a complicated turn. As their advocate, I’m expected to be available, to offer clarity and reassurance, especially now when every detail matters. I glance at the foreman, then at my phone, torn between the urgent call of safety and the pressing need for legal advice. My mind races, anxiety tightening my chest. If I answer, I risk breaking site rules and letting my team down. If I ignore the call, I fail my client when they need me most. The alarm blares, my phone buzzes, and I stand frozen, caught between two worlds, each demanding all of me at once.
